Williams ends three-year title drought in Auckland|12/01/2020|"Serena Williams won her first title since the 2017 Australian Open with a 6-3 6-4 victory over Jessica Pegula at the Auckland Classic on Sunday but was unable to complete the perfect week in New Zealand when she lost the doubles final.
The 38-year-old Williams
column2: who said she would donate all her prize money to Australian bushfire relief funds
column3: and good friend Caroline Wozniacki were beaten by American duo Asia Muhammad and Taylor Townsend 6-4 6-4.

column1: The result meant that Wozniacki was unable to complete her own fairytale farewell to a tournament with which she has become synonymous
column2: having played in New Zealand’s largest city every year since 2015.

column1: The 29-year-old Dane
column2: who was beaten by Pegula in the singles semi-finals
column3: is retiring after the Australian Open
column4: which runs from Jan 20 to Feb. 2.

column1: “I have loved coming back here
column2: ” Wozniacki said after tournament organisers made a special presentation before the doubles trophy was given to Muhammad and Townsend.

column1: “Serena
column2: thank you playing doubles with me
column3: it has been so much fun and the only regrets I have is that we didn’t do this sooner.

column1: “I have had such a blast and it is rare that I have this much fun on court and it was a really fun way to finish off in Auckland.”
Williams’ singles victory
column2: however
column3: gave the American her 73rd WTA title and broke a near three-year drought
column4: despite having appeared in five finals since she clinched her 23rd Grand Slam crown with a win at the Australian Open in 2017.

column1: She is chasing Australian Margaret Court’s record 24 Grand Slam singles titles
column2: but has lost two Wimbledon and two U.S. Open finals since her 6-4 6-4 victory over elder sister Venus in Melbourne.

column1: “It feels good
column2: it has been a long time
column3: ” Williams said. “I played an incredible opponent in Jessica and honestly it was a great match.”

column1: Williams had struggled for consistency earlier in the week
column2: but sent an ominous message to the Australian Open field when she demolished promising teenager Amanda Anisimova 6-1 6-1 in their semi-final and then beat an impressive Pegula on Sunday.

column1: “I was definitely improving as the week went on and I needed to because I had some tough matches
column2: ” Williams said.

column1: “I feel fortunate and blessed to be out here and to be healthy and to play. I have been playing for so long and been through so much and I’m happy to be doing something I love.”

Kenyan scientist Muthoni Masinde created an app that predicts droughts|30/05/2020|"An app is combining weather station data with the traditional knowledge of African farmers to predict droughts.
To help prepare farmers for the effects of climate change
column2: Kenyan computer scientist Muthoni Masinde has created mobile platform ITIKI.

column1: The name stands for Information Technology and Indigenous Knowledge
column2: and the platform sends farmers drought forecasts via an app or SMS message.

column1: Although it uses meteorological data
column2: Masinde says most African farmers can better relate to the traditional knowledge that is also used to formulate the platform’s predictions.

column1: “I grew up in a [Kenyan] village and I noticed that most farmers do not have any form of science to tell [them] when to plant
column2: ” Masinde told CNN Business.

column1: “They watch insects
column2: they watch the behavior of animals and then they make a decision
column3: ‘I think it’ll rain in two weeks’ time.'”

column1: ITIKI employs young people in farming communities to gather photos and updates about animal behavior and local vegetation
column2: such as which trees are flowering.

column1: They capture their findings on the ITIKI app
column2: and ITIKI collates this information with data from local weather stations to model weather patterns months in advance.

column1: Farmers can subscribe to the service for just a few cents
column2: and receive regular updates in their local language
column3: helping them make early decisions about which crops they should grow and whether to sell or save their produce.

column1: Economic impact of drought
Many African countries are especially vulnerable to climate change and small-scale farmers in particular
column2: who rely on rainfall for their harvests
column3: could face poverty and food insecurity

column1: That could have major economic repercussions. Agriculture contributes about 15% to Africa’s total GDP
column2: according to a 2017 UN report
column3: and accounts for around half of the continent’s employment
column4: according to the African Development Bank.

column1: Now a professor at the Central University of Technology Free State
column2: in South Africa
column3: Masinde launched the app in 2016 in Kenya
column4: where agriculture makes up around a third of GDP.

column1: “Investments in climate adaptation solutions
column2: especially targeting small scale farmers
column3: would lead to GDP growth [in Africa]

column1: She added that African governments tend to react to drought and extreme weather
column2: rather than proactively planning for these events.

column1: “We do not prepare for [drought]
column2: ” she said. “It’s like we just wake up and discover that people in rural Kenya are starving
column3: that people on one side of the country have no rain.”

column1: Masinde says ITIKI is now used by more than 15
column2: 000 farmers in Kenya
column3: Mozambique and South Africa. Since farmers started using the app their crop yields have increased by an average of 11%

column1: ITIKI has received $750
column2: 000 in funding from the US and South African governments
column3: which will be used to scale up operations. By the end of this year
column4: Masinde hopes to have signed up over 100
